title: Review Mining
summary:
This paper proposes a unified, feature-based opinion mining framework that goes beyond document-level sentiment classification by extracting product features, the opinions expressed about them, and their polarity, then presenting the results as concise summaries with interactive visualizations. It argues that fully automatic opinion mining remains difficult because customer reviews are heterogeneous, semi-structured, and often express feature sentiment indirectly across sentences. The core goal is to distill fine-grained, feature-level sentiment that is more useful for customers and manufacturers than a single positive, negative, or neutral label for an entire review.

The proposed system architecture integrates multiple modules in sequence to reduce noise and improve feature–opinion pairing accuracy, especially when features are referenced via pronouns. Key components include:
- Subjectivity vs objectivity analysis at sentence level using supervised learning (unigram representation plus statistical and linguistic features) to filter factual text from opinion-bearing text.
- Feature and opinion extraction using a combination of parsing and rule-based patterns, plus a backtracking-based anaphora resolution step to bind opinions to earlier-mentioned features.
- A feasibility analyzer that removes noisy feature–opinion pairs using reliability scores derived from a customized HITS-style bipartite graph model, treating feature–opinion pairs as hubs and review documents as authorities.
- A sentiment analyzer that assigns polarity to opinion words using supervised machine learning and features drawn from association measures such as PMI, mutual information, chi-square, and log-likelihood ratio, along with linguistic cues like negation, tf-idf, and modifiers.

The paper also describes an Opinion Summarization and Visualization System that lets users browse crawled reviews and see feature-based sentiment summaries without reading full documents. Results are stored in a structured, lightweight representation and rendered with bar and pie charts, plus color highlighting that links feature words, opinion words, and the supporting snippets; the interface includes panels for review lists, metadata, and extracted feature–opinion results, with pop-up views for per-feature sentiment percentages and opinion-score summaries. The conclusion reiterates that feature-based mining with subjectivity filtering, anaphora-aware binding, reliability screening, and word-level sentiment modeling helps address key gaps, but that end-to-end automation remains an open research challenge.

*However, development of a fully automatic opinion mining and sentiment analysis system is still elusive.*

*document-level opinion mining approaches fail to provide insight about users sentiment on individual features of a subject.*
